text: Patient: So, I say, yeah, I tell her can she get a script so I can call my insurance and see where I can get a cheap one at. Doctor: Yeah. I don’t think I will be able to justify a scooter for you. Okay? Based on just this disease. Believe me, I have given that script to other people, and it has not worked for people who are sick or older than you. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, I don’t think it will work. Okay? Uh, beyond that, if you want to see a neurologist, get tested, and see if they would be willing to give you, that’s perfectly okay with me. Patient: Uh, what, a what? Doctor: Neurologist. A nerve specialist. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because they have to show that either your nerves are not working, your, uh, legs are not working, something or the other before we Patient: I wonder why they ain’t working good. Doctor: Yeah. So, they will say, “Did you try a walker? Did you try a this or that?” Patient: I, I, uh got a cane. I had a walker. Doctor: Okay. Now,

text: Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: but before I get to that let me just tell you what standard of care will be. One might be the vaccine trial which is basically getting your own blood cells to wake up and try to kill the cancer yourself because right now it’s kind of sleeping on the job Mr. S____. You have cancer and your immune cells are like ho-hum, nothing’s happening. It’s still letting the cancer do what it wants so that’s an FDA approved treatment. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: No cure but we have some long-term survival benefits so that’s one option. The other option is a different type of chemo so a cousin of the chemo that you had earlier this year. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: The third one is a pill um and it’s a like a super hormone pill that complements what’s going on with your Lupron injections that oh, you love so much. Those are standard of care like we have no studies going on at Karmanos. I could pick one off the shelf and we’d be good to go Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: and you know, depending on what your scans show, I actually would favor Provenge, which is the vaccine therapy, because it’s almost like a flu shot. We don’t really know what happens to the PSA but we do know that if you get it in people who get it Patient: Is that a shot or is that through? Doctor: So, here’s where it gets a little complicated. You know, the flu shot is also like a vaccine. That, you know, you just get here. But, in cancer it’s a little bit more complicated. So, what we would do is actually send you to the Red Cross right across the street. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: They hook you up to a machine and then they take out your cells so they’re not using my cells or anybody else’s cells. They’re taking out your cells, your immune cells so that when they take it they ship it to Atlanta so if you’ve never been to Atlanta, your cells will be. They wake it up and then they ship it back to me, the like better version of you and then I reinfuse it back to you so that your cells know to find the cancer. That’s the thought of how that medicine works. So, we do that, let’s say the Red Cross on a Monday, I get your stuff back like on a Thursday and then I reinfuse it to you on a Thursday. We do that 3 times and then the treatment is done. It’s self-limited. Okay. Patient: So, that’s your immune system.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: But you know I never just do the standard routine anything. (Laughs) Patient: I been here long enough, I just, I am not new here. Doctor: Yes. text: Patient: - and then six months from not it could develop someplace else. Family Member: I guess that’s what I’m saying. Patient: Oh. You’re saying this is where it’s landed now, which is not to say it’s not going to in a month, two months, three months, land somewhere else. Doctor: Right. Family Member: So we’re still kind of up in the air because this is nothing we can cure because of the type of cancer that it is and there’s no option to remove the lymph node. I don’t know Doctor: That’s correct. Family Member: That’s correct. Okay, okay. So with him trying to maintain quality of life and, and, and, uhm you know stay upright knowing that he has this and that he’s against hormone therapy but also still leaning with the fact that there’s the other foot to drop. Doctor: Uh hum. Family Member: You’re saying the radiation is a viable option if that’s the route he chooses to go but your recommendation is hormone? text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Standard stuff. Trials. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So standard stuff, you’ve now had kind of the standard hormone treatments. Both of the two that we have. Patient: Okay. text: Patient: I see. Doctor: So how, so a lot of the research is how do we get those cells attractive- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: to go in the cancer? And the most extreme way would be give you a new immune system. Give you somebody else’s immune system where those cancers were foreign. Patient: I see. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
